articles.headline: Elections Offer Respite for Biden, but Show Disparity Between Him and His Party
articles.snippet: Tuesday’s results were a win for the president after demoralizing poll numbers. But some strategists argue the outcomes show only that Democrats are doing well, not necessarily the president.
articles.abstract: Tuesday’s results were a win for the president after demoralizing poll numbers. But some strategists argue the outcomes show only that Democrats are doing well, not necessarily the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Poll? What poll? The Democratic victories in Tuesday’s off-year elections gave President Biden’s White House some desperately needed breathing space just when it needed it.

articles.headline: Disney Adds 5 Million Streaming Subscribers
articles.snippet: The company is in the midst of a major transformation, exploring options for traditional businesses like ESPN.
articles.abstract: The company is in the midst of a major transformation, exploring options for traditional businesses like ESPN.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Robert A. Iger approaches the first anniversary of his return as chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, he delivered a strong earnings report on Wednesday, telling investors that the company added roughly five million subscribers to its streaming services in the last three months.

articles.headline: Striking Actors and Hollywood Studios Agree to a Deal
articles.snippet: The agreement all but ends one of the longest labor crises in the history of the entertainment industry. Union members still have to approve the deal.
articles.abstract: The agreement all but ends one of the longest labor crises in the history of the entertainment industry. Union members still have to approve the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the longest labor crises in Hollywood history is finally coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes, John Koblin and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: With the Strikes Over, the Mood in Hollywood Is Decidedly Mixed
articles.snippet: Celebratory feelings are competing with resentment over the work stoppage and worries about the business era that is coming.
articles.abstract: Celebratory feelings are competing with resentment over the work stoppage and worries about the business era that is coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: It should be a rapturous time in Hollywood.

articles.headline: Heat Pump Installations Slow, Impeding Biden’s Climate Goals
articles.snippet: The devices can heat and cool homes more efficiently than furnaces and air-conditioners, but their sales have slowed because of higher interest rates and a slow rollout of federal incentives.
articles.abstract: The devices can heat and cool homes more efficiently than furnaces and air-conditioners, but their sales have slowed because of higher interest rates and a slow rollout of federal incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: More Americans are buying heat pumps, an environmentally friendly alternative to furnaces and air-conditioners that can significantly lower monthly energy bills. But the pace of installations has slowed in the past year, posing an obstacle to the Biden administration’s climate plans.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: ‘Our Family Can Have a Future’: Ford Workers on a New Union Contract
articles.snippet: A couple who work at a Ford factory that was on strike for 41 days said the terms of a tentative contract agreement would be transformative for them.
articles.abstract: A couple who work at a Ford factory that was on strike for 41 days said the terms of a tentative contract agreement would be transformative for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before autoworkers went on strike in September, Dave and Bailey Hodge were struggling to juggle the demands of working at a Ford Motor plant in Michigan and raising their young family.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Nic Antaya

articles.headline: After Antisemitic Attacks, Colleges Debate What Kind of Speech Is Out of Bounds
articles.snippet: Pro-Palestinian students say that they are speaking up for an oppressed people, but critics say that their rhetoric is deeply offensive.
articles.abstract: Pro-Palestinian students say that they are speaking up for an oppressed people, but critics say that their rhetoric is deeply offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days after the Hamas attack on Israel, Max Strozenberg, a first-year student at Northwestern University, experienced a couple of jarring incidents.
articles.byline: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Getting Hollywood Back Up and Running Won’t Be Easy
articles.snippet: With the industry hustling to make up for months of lost work, juggling production schedules and the availability of actors and crew members will be complicated.
articles.abstract: With the industry hustling to make up for months of lost work, juggling production schedules and the availability of actors and crew members will be complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daisy Edgar-Jones, the 25-year-old British actress with an increasingly crowded dance card, will soon experience just how complicated Hollywood’s rush to return to work is going to be.

articles.headline: WeWork’s Bankruptcy Tests Claims of a Co-Working Revolution
articles.snippet: The business of offering offices on flexible, short leases will survive the company’s troubles, but commercial real estate experts say it will probably remain a niche.
articles.abstract: The business of offering offices on flexible, short leases will survive the company’s troubles, but commercial real estate experts say it will probably remain a niche.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its heyday a few years ago, WeWork said it would reinvent offices. But the company never created a sustainable business or changed how most people worked.

articles.headline: Biden Finalizes Significant Overhaul in Federal Regulations
articles.snippet: New rules from the Office of Management and Budget will change how the federal government weighs costs, enabling new efforts on climate change and poverty.
articles.abstract: New rules from the Office of Management and Budget will change how the federal government weighs costs, enabling new efforts on climate change and poverty.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has overhauled how the federal government assesses the costs and benefits of regulation and some government spending programs, clearing a path for more aggressive efforts to fight climate change and help the poor.

articles.headline: A Bundle of 18th-Century Love Letters Is Unsealed at Last
articles.snippet: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
articles.abstract: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ink has barely faded, and the paper has only slightly yellowed. For nearly 250 years, the letters, more than 100 of them, sat sealed in Britain’s National Archives, unopened and unexamined until a history professor stumbled upon them. He found, to his delight, a treasure trove bearing intimate details about romance and daily life in mid-18th-century France.
